awd_titl_txt: Presidential Young Investigator Award - New Searches for    Primeval Galaxies
awd_abstract_narration: The birth and development of the universe will be studied by                    observing light from astronomical objects in the distant past.                  The light from these objects was generated up to 15 billion years               ago.  The light will reveal the properties of these objects, such               as galaxies,  that existed when the universe was younger.  The                  largest telescopes, using sensitive electronic detectors known as               charge-coupled devices (CCDs), will be used to make the                         observations.  Extremely fast computers, using specially developed              software, will be used to analyze and interpret the data.  The                  data will be used to try to determine how galaxies form and evolve              and to examine the structure of the universe moments after the                  "Big Bang".  Data from the Hubble Space Telescope will be acquired              after its launch.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of California-Santa Cruz Lick Observatory
